title: Quantification of Super Duplex Steel Phases by Processing of Backscattered Electron Images
content: Super duplex stainless steels are steels that combine excellent corrosion resistance with high mechanical resistance values, in addition to having high impact toughness. These characteristics are attributed to a fine two-phase microstructure composed of ferrite (α) and austenite (γ) presented in similar proportions. The presence of the ferritic phase confers a specific increase in the mechanical strength limit and resistance to stress corrosion cracking in these steels, when compared to austenitic stainless steels. Superduplex stainless steels differ from the known Duplex stainless steels due to their higher level of resistance to pitting corrosion determined by some alloy elements [1, 2].
